newsitem.title: FRENCH GUIANA: Delayed Ariane rocket launch set for April 16.
newsitem.headline: Delayed Ariane rocket launch set for April 16.

text.p: The delayed launch of Western Europe's 95th Ariane rocket has been rescheduled for April 16, space officials said on Tuesday.

"All checks on the spacecraft-launcher adapter have been satisfactorily completed in Kourou, (French Guiana) and the launch preparation campaign has resumed," the Paris-based Arianespace company said in a statement.
"The liftoff of Ariane... is now scheduled for Wednesday April 16," it said.
The launch was originally planned for for April 11 but postponed last week when a problem was detected in the connection between the launcher and satellite payload.
The Ariane-4 rocket is scheduled to launch the THAICOM 3 satellite for Thailand and the BSAT-1 direct broadcast satellite for Japan.
The Ariane rocket series is launched from the European Space Agency (ESA) launch centre in Kourou, French Guiana on the northeast coast of South America.
Arianespace leads the commercial satellite launch market and has successfully placed into orbit 18 heavy satellites since January 1996 aboard 12 Ariane rockets.
The maiden launch of the new Ariane-5 rocket ended in disaster last June when it exploded shortly after take-off. A new flight is scheduled for September.
Arianespace said its launch backlog for Ariane-4 was 41 satellites, worth an estimated $3.5 billion.
